etymologies: early 16th century: from Anglo-Latin impropriat- ‘appropriated’, from the verb impropriare, based on Latin proprius ‘one's own, proper’

definitions: grant (an ecclesiastical benefice) to a corporation or person as their property

examples.text: the rectory itself was impropriated to the convent
the estates were transferred to the Crown in exchange for a few impropriated rectories

shortDefinitions: grant ecclesiastical benefice to corporation or person as their property

definitions: place (tithes or ecclesiastical property) in lay hands

examples.text: tithes were destined for the upkeep of the parish clergy but often impropriated by monasteries or laymen

shortDefinitions: place tithes or ecclesiastical property in lay hands
